title: How China Plans to Avert an Evergrande Financial Crisis
content: Control of the banking system gives Beijing the tools to stop a broader collapse, officials believe, while censorship and police powers can stifle protests.

title: ‘Everyday Is Doomsday’: New Limits Give Chinese E-Gamers Whiplash
content: China has a complex relationship with video games. New government rules for minors have made it even more so.

title: Want a Can’t Miss Productivity Tip? Forget About Being Productive.
content: People and industries measure how productive they are in similar ways. This extended period of remote work for many has revealed how flawed that can be.

title: Long Hours, Low Pay, Loneliness and a Booming Industry
content: The ranks of home health aides are expected to grow more than any other job in the next decade. What kind of work are they being asked to do?

title: Robinhood Hits Campus, Where Credit Card Companies Fear to Tread
content: The company plans to hit up college coffee shops to spread the word about its services. When credit card companies did it a generation ago, Congress got involved.

title: Could This Covid Wave Reverse the Recovery? Here’s What to Watch.
content: Some businesses are still hurting, and federal aid has wound down. But economists see sources of resilience and signs of strength.

title: In Race for 5G, Alarm and Security Services Get Stuck in the Middle
content: Covid-19 shutdowns and chip shortages have made it more difficult to upgrade devices and meet a deadline set by AT&T.

title: A Path to Financial Security That Doesn’t Lead to a 401(k)
content: Some Black and Hispanic millennials are looking to alternatives like real estate or entrepreneurship, or to trading stock on their own.

title: The Week in Business: A Debt Deadline Looms
content: The Fed indicated it was planning to slow down its purchases of government bonds as soon as November. And food delivery workers in New York gained protections.

title: This Lab Charges $380 for a Covid Test. Is That What Congress Had in Mind?
content: Insurers say it’s price-gouging, but a law left an opening for some labs to charge any price they wished.

title: A 3-D Model Built With Public Records and Phone Calls
content: For an interactive article on business inside the Empire State Building, a New York Times team turned to interviews with tenants, vacancy listings, promotional materials and real estate data.

title: How Record Rain and Officials’ Mistakes Led to Drownings on a Subway
content: The deluge in the city of Zhengzhou revealed how China’s years of go-go construction had left its cities vulnerable to climate change.

title: One Solution to a Shortage of Skilled Workers? Diversify the Construction Industry.
content: President Biden’s infrastructure plan would create a hiring challenge, but also an opportunity to recruit from communities that the industry has long ignored.

title: The Surveillance Apparatus That Surrounded Britney Spears
content: An account by a former employee of the security team hired by Ms. Spears’s father created the most detailed portrait yet of the singer’s life under 13 years of conservatorship.

title: Cliff Freeman, Adman Who Asked, ‘Where’s the Beef?,’ Dies at 80
content: His humorous touch was evident in commercials for Wendy’s, Little Caesars, Fox Sports and many other clients. “We have to win with wit,” he once said.

title: PG&E Faces Criminal Charges Over Fatal 2020 Wildfire in California
content: Charges including manslaughter arise from a blaze that killed four last year. A state inquiry said the utility’s power lines were involved.

title: Faith vs. a Full Week of Work
content: You shouldn’t have to forgo religious observance to do your job.

title: Senators say they pulled out of a Boston Globe conference to back a union.
content: Senators Edward J. Markey and Elizabeth Warren said they had declined to participate in solidarity with journalists who are in a contract dispute.

title: ‘The View’ pulls two hosts mid-show after they test positive for the coronavirus.
content: Ana Navarro and Sunny Hostin, were directed to leave the set live on the air while Vice President Kamala Harris waited backstage for an in-person interview.

title: Disney Sues to Keep Complete Rights to Marvel Characters
content: The company filed several lawsuits seeking to invalidate copyright-termination notices served by artists and illustrators involved with creating superheroes like Spider-Man and Thor.

title: At Art Basel, Everyone’s Playing It Safe
content: Dealers brought familiar works to the flagship Swiss fair, and the event’s organizers soothed nervous exhibitors with reassuring gestures.

title: He Taught Ancient Texts at Oxford. Now He Is Accused of Stealing Some.
content: Hobby Lobby, the craft chain that helped build a collection for the Museum of the Bible, has sued a former Oxford lecturer, asserting he sold it stolen artifacts.

title: The C.E.O. Other C.E.O.s Turn to for Advice
content: Rich Lesser, who has run Boston Consulting Group for eight years, is stepping down at a moment of enormous change.

title: China Detains Business Chiefs as Its Corporate Crusade Expands
content: The seizure of the top two leaders of HNA Group comes as speculation swirls over whether Beijing will bail out another troubled giant, Evergrande.

title: A Push for Social Security to Resume Mailing Annual Updates
content: The government has been urging people to create online accounts. But most haven’t, which means they can’t regularly check for errors.

title: Pandemic Changes the World of Horse Auctions
content: Traditional speculators, known as pinhookers, are now vying with online buyers looking to invest in something new. The new bidders are driving up prices.

title: Here Come the Crypto Rules
content: The urgency among regulators to rein in the crypto industry has generated a flurry of lobbying all over Washington.

title: China Cracks Down Harder on Cryptocurrency With New Ban
content: The clampdown comes as China’s central bank has been testing its own digital currency. The price of Bitcoin dropped on the news.

title: The U.S. could run out of cash to pay its bills as early as Oct. 15, analysts say.
content: The analysis showed a narrower window during which the United States could default on its debt. The Treasury has said it has no official contingency plan if the debt limit is breached.

title: Why Reparations Are Needed to Close the Racial Wealth Gap
content: The U.S. government’s debt to emancipated slaves and their descendants is more than 155 years overdue, an economist says.

title: That Comment Someone Left on Facebook? It Can Get You Sued.
content: Australia’s top court has said media companies can be held liable for replies to their posts, prompting some to step back from the platform.

title: An Insider Details the ‘Black Box’ of Money and Power in China
content: A memoir by a well-connected businessman offers insights into the Communist Party’s thinking as it tightens its grip on the private sector.

title: Federal Panel Recommends Booster Shots, Opening New Campaign Against the Virus
content: Scientific advisers to the C.D.C. endorsed additional doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for older Americans but not for health care workers, in a possible rift with regulators.

title: Residents of Troubled Supertall Tower Seek $125 Million in Damages
content: The condo board at 432 Park Avenue is suing the developers for construction and design defects that have led to floods, faulty elevators, and electrical explosions.
